title: Magnetic field - circular arcs with switch

content.question: The diagram shows a small portion of a circuit. The rest of the circuit, which includes a power source, is not shown. The switch controls the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> in a circular arc section of wire with length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> for Position <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and length <math alttext="2 L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi></math> for Position <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The magnetic field strength <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> is measured at the point shown, which is at the center of the circular arcs. <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> is twice as great with the switch in Position <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> as it is with the switch in Position <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. What does this indicate about the currents <math alttext="I sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="I sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> with the switch in positions <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, respectively?
